Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Experimental and Theoretical Investigation of Sediment Supply and Sorting in Meandering Rivers
Award.AbstractNarration:
A non-technical description of the project's broader significance and importance

Meandering river channels are one of the most iconic features of the landscape and the migration of these large bends in rivers are a direct concern to communities and landowners along the flood plain. The mechanisms of meander formation and migration have long attracted the attention of scientists and engineers. There remain, however, considerable gaps in knowledge of these channels, especially regarding the dynamic interactions among sediment supply, grain-size of river bed sediment, and the river-bed topography. The scientific focus of this CAREER project is to explore these relationships using laboratory flume experiments, analytical theory, and numerical modeling. The results of this research will have applications to pressing societal issues such as flood protection, stream channel maintenance, river restoration, and dam removal. The research will be integrated with an educational and outreach program designed to introduce K-12 students and the public to important issues in river science and management, and to improve the educational experience of undergraduate and graduate engineering students.

A technical description of the project

The scientific objectives of this project are 1) to investigate how channel curvature affects equilibrium patterns of bed topography and surface sorting, 2) to examine how changes in sediment supply affect sorting and bed topography in meandering channels, and 3) to explore the interactions of free and forced bars in meandering channels of mixed grain size sediment and variable sediment supply. A comprehensive suite of flume experiments will be conducted to test several hypotheses. The first experiments will use detailed flow and sediment transport measurements to examine the mechanisms controlling equilibrium conditions at different meander curvatures. The second experiments will focus on questions related to sediment supply effects on bar-pool morphology and the interactions between free and forced bars in curved channels. In conjunction with Italian colleagues, the project will develop a theoretical model for river meandering that incorporates sediment supply and grain sorting. This new model, along with two-dimensional numerical models, will extend knowledge of processes of meandering channels beyond the scales achievable in the laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Meandering river channels are one of the most iconic features in geomorphology and have long attracted the attention of scientists and engineers. The wide range of water depths and velocities that develop in meandering channels, along with the strong bed sediment sorting they usually display, makes these areas important habitats for diverse aquatic ecosystems. However, research on meandering rivers has left open questions about the specific mechanisms responsible for developing the topography and sorting in these channels, particularly under conditions where the sediment supplied to the channel is changing. In this project, we performed laboratory flume experiments and used numerical modeling to better understand how channel curvature affects equilibrium patterns of bed topography and surface sorting in meandering channels, and how these channels respond to changes in sediment supply.

 

Flume experiments were performed in a wide channel with a single bend where we made detailed measurements of the bed topography, bed sorting, bed load transport, and three-dimensional velocity field. Our experiments revealed that the mechanism responsible for developing fine point bars and coarse pools is different for gravel-bed and sand-bed rivers. In our case – a scaled gravel-bed river – size-selective transport appears to be the primary mechanism for developing fine bars and coarse pools. This contrasts with sand-bedded meandering channels, where generally all particle sizes are fully mobile and sorting is more dependent on the balance of secondary flows and gravitational effects.

 

A second set of experiments was conducted in a narrower channel with several meander bends, which broadened our understanding of how meandering gravel-bed rivers respond to changes in sediment supply. In these experiments, we doubled the sediment supply and observed changes in bed sorting, bedform abundance, bar-pool relief, and overall channel slope. To explain these observations, we proposed a conceptual model wherein the channel undergoes a temporal progression of responses from smaller to larger spatial scales, with the total response potential at each scale related to the conditions and constraints at that scale.

 

Characterizing form and grain roughness in gravel bed rivers, and parameterizing roughness in computational hydraulic models, is a major challenge in fluvial geomorphology and hydraulics. Our experiments produced new understanding on how to extract form roughness and grain-scale roughness from very dense three-dimensional topographic point clouds, how to use those data to characterize roughness, and how to use the roughness data in hydraulic modeling. We developed techniques to filter very dense, high-resolution topographic point clouds to generate ‘form roughness’ and ‘grain roughness’ grids. The grain roughness data were used to characterize patterns of bed sorting, and to calculate a roughness height appropriate for use in hydraulic models. Model results using this calibration-free approach compared well with experimental measurements and were not significantly different from the best results we could obtain through a traditional roughness calibration procedure.

 

 

As a CAREER award, this project included a significant education and outreach component. We developed the week-long Alliance River Science STEM Institute program for high school students, which took place every summer for four years. The program is affiliated with the Alliance Partnership, which consists of ten Colorado high schools that serve populations with a high percentage of students eligible for free and reduced lunches, a diverse racial and ethnic makeup of the student population, and a high percentage of students who represent the first generation of their family who may attend college. High school participants from these schools lived on campus in residence halls with undergraduate mentors, and they performed field-based activities related to river science, such as collecting topographic data around a stream with survey equipment and a terrestrial laser scanner, investigating stream ecology by collecting macroinvertebrate samples and electrofishing, and performing flume experiments at the CSU hydraulics laboratory. Participant surveys indicated that this program made them feel more prepared for the process of applying to college and increased their likelihood of pursuing environmental science in their future education and career. Additionally, we performed demonstrations for the RAM Academy, the Native American STEM Institute (NASTEMI), and CSU Engineering Exploration Days. These outreach activities demonstrated to over 200 middle and high school students that environmental science is an option as an academic major and career.
